Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: Vulnerabilities in Critical Global Trade Infrastructures

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Division.LongName: Division Of Behavioral and Cognitive Sci

Award.AbstractNarration:
Scientific interest in infrastructure has tried to understand the mechanical, human, and natural forces that impact the flow of information and services. These infrastructures have become increasingly dependent on the global movement of goods and peoples. The global systems that deliver these resources, however, are inevitably funneled through bottlenecks or "chokepoints", such as canals, tunnels, maritime straights, border crossings, etc. Constricting the flow of materials and people, such chokepoints are both vital to national and economic interests, and uniquely vulnerable, dynamic, and prone to disturbances. Not surprisingly, governments, corporations, and communities have taken a keen interest in securing and regulating these sites. Little is known, however, about how these passageways actually work. This collaborative project seeks to explore how local communities, environments, and infrastructures interact to allow passage through these sites (or not), as well how ordinary (and sometimes extraordinary) events at chokepoints affect economic systems, security, and lives well beyond these points of passage.

Christopher Middleton and Gabriela Valdivia of the University of North Carolina at Chapel Hill, Ashley Carse of Vanderbilt University, Jatin Dua of the University of Michigan at Ann Arbor, Elizabeth Dunn of Indiana University, and Jason Cons of the University of Texas at Austin, will explore six chokepoints around the world. Each member of the team is an expert in their region of study. Each will focus on a particular kind of chokepoint. These include: the Panama Canal, a tunnel in Russia, a land bridge in India, an oil-refinery and pipelines in Ecuador, a network of rivers in Bangladesh, and a maritime strait leading into the Red Sea. The researchers will utilize extensive interviews, observation, and first-person engagement with officials, workers, and chokepoint residents in order to understand the distinctly human dimensions of these transit zones. Bringing together data from around the world, this study will provide a strategic reassessment of the global movement of goods, information, and people by examining these vital and dynamic points of national and world interest. The results will speak directly to current concerns over migration, security, and economic wellbeing. In doing so, this project promises to alter the ways governments, industries, and others understand and engage with these critical transit points of the world today.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This collaborative research brought together social scientists from multiple universities to investigate Vulnerabilities in Critical Global Trade Infrastructures. The researchers focused their investigations on chokepoints: canals, tunnels, pipelines, geopolitical corridors, etc. Chokepoints are sites that constrict--or "choke"--the flow of information, populations, and goods. With new canals, pipelines, tunnels, economic corridors, and logistics hubs being built every day, chokepoints remain a source of vital public interest. Not surprisingly, governments, militaries, corporations, and communities have taken a keen interest in securing and regulating these sites. Yet little is known about how these passageways actually work, how peoples, environments, and infrastructure interact to allow passage through these sites (or not), and how dynamics at these bottlenecks are reshaping life at--and ultimately far beyond--their points of passage.

To fill this gap in our collective knowledge about the networks and critical passageways upon which the world depends, this collaborative study sent six experts in ethnography to chokepoints around the globe in order to develop a comparative understanding of these sites and their critical importance to the world.  Leveraging the qualitative strengths of ethnographic study, the investigators relied on interviews and participant observation to bring out the human dimensions of these key arteries of today's circulatory systems.  At six exemplary chokepoints, the researchers examined: how global forces shape life at chokepoints; how human and environmental activity at these bottlenecks enables, disrupts, and transforms global flows; and what kinds of life-worlds, politics, and ecologies emerge at these sites. Through comparative ethnographic engagement, the study developed new understandings of the global flows and frictions that adhere these sites, such that we may better understand their vitality and vulnerability at the present conjuncture. 

Our findings bear upon a range of current economic, security, and policy concerns. Because chokepoints are difficult to bypass, they are often seen as obstacles--logistical problems to be navigated, worked around, or otherwise resolved. But chokepoints can also be sites of opportunity. More than that, they are nodes where sociopolitical, financial, and ecological concerns are negotiated and power dynamics turn expectations upside down. Useful for enacting governmental or economic control, chokepoints are also sites where the dominant become vulnerable, connectivity becomes a liability, and marginalized voices and forms of agency are amplified. A strike or natural disaster which shuts down a port can send shock waves through the economy.  A congested canal slows global trade to a crawl--the weakest link in an otherwise accelerating supply chain. A security threat to a vulnerable geo-political corridor paralyzes movement between countries and rewrites their international relations. A marginalized community or social movement blockades a key highway, grabbing the attention of an otherwise inattentive government. What happens in and around chokepoints, our research shows, is as critical as what circulates through them. This project accordingly has sought to understand the human dimensions of these sites, so as to foster a more thorough understanding of how these sites work, for whom, and how they impart critical opportunities--and vulnerabilities--to global trade infrastructures.
